title: Are they really going to stick with "Challenger Ahri"?
body:
I don't understand why they don't like "Dauntless". 

Do they think we're THAT stupid that we won't understand what dauntless means?

and even then, people can easily search for it's definition.

I DON'T UNDERSTAND WHYYYYYYY

Also, I've read pretty much every thread that popped up about the topic - and I've yet to come across anyone who genuinely likes Challenger Ahri as a name. Almost every single post that didn't agree with the general sentiment has been expressing indifference similar to yours - "it's just a name", "weho cares about the name" etc. "I liked Challenger Ahri better" - not even once.

Within said minority, mostly everyone may dislike the name, but I am speaking about players in a general sense. And, like I said, anyone who is content with the name probably isn't going to post on the forums. There is no need for them to do so.

The key word in what you said is *'a'*. It *can* be used to represent a demographic. More specifically, a demographic of boards users. Theoretically, you could forcibly decide it is representative of the entire community's opinion, but it would be an erroneous and flawed system. Especially when you consider that a simple in-game poll could be much more effective, accessible, and easy.

It is very similar to the way in which only a minority of U.S. citizens actually vote--whether in a county, state, or federal election/proposition of anything. The decisions made in those elections/propositions are decisions that the rest of the population will have to live by and accept as a part of their daily life. Does the rest of the population have the option to vote? Yes. Should they vote? Yes. I am simply saying that we should acknowledge that there are many other players out there who don't use the boards or go on rants on Facebook/Twitter/Reddit. I am saying that these unseen and unheard people may or may not have the same opinion as the more vocal individuals.

Also, examples like test groups and polls don't work on the internet, where much of the difficulties of the physical world can be bypassed so easily. (See my earlier proposition of an in-game poll.) Test groups are flawed as well, however, there are valid reasons that companies don't reach out to entire human population to test their products. It is simply the next best thing. Test groups and polls are the closest companies can get to a representative opinion, and it *still* has a high degree of scientific error.
